body_html:
The issue seems to broil down to replacing
indices = [[i,j] for i in range(0, dims_H[0]) for j in range(xyz.k, xyz.k+dims_H[1])]
with a TensorFlow graph implementation. I believe in principle this is expressible using existing ops; some of the relevant ones seem to be tf.shape(...)[0] (which will give you the correct batch_size at execution time) and tf.range(), etc. Could you give those a try?
body_text:
The issue seems to broil down to replacing
indices = [[i,j] for i in range(0, dims_H[0]) for j in range(xyz.k, xyz.k+dims_H[1])]
with a TensorFlow graph implementation.  I believe in principle this is expressible using existing ops; some of the relevant ones seem to be tf.shape(...)[0] (which will give you the correct batch_size at execution time) and tf.range(), etc.  Could you give those a try?
body:
The issue seems to broil down to replacing 
`indices = [[i,j] for i in range(0, dims_H[0]) for j in range(xyz.k, xyz.k+dims_H[1])]`
with a TensorFlow graph implementation.  I believe in principle this is expressible using existing ops; some of the relevant ones seem to be `tf.shape(...)[0]` (which will give you the correct batch_size at execution time) and `tf.range()`, etc.  Could you give those a try?
